title: Pro Log: Recovery setback for Evenepoel; UCI bans celebrating teammates; Australian nationals results; New kits for EF and British Cycling
content:
Cyclist
Pro Log: Recovery setback for Evenepoel; UCI bans celebrating teammates; Australian nationals results; New kits for EF and British Cycling

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. Here’s a rundown of the latest cyclocross results before we get started:

  • Belgium National Championship, Elite Women, Sat 11th Jan: 1st Marion Norbert Riberolle, 53min 18sec; 2nd Laura Verdonschot, +45sec; 3rd Julie Brouwers +1min 07sec. 
  • Belgium National Championship, Elite Men, Sun 12th Jan: 1st Thibau Nys, 1hr 03min 05sec; 2nd Laurens Sweek, +09sec; 3rd Toon Aerts, +11sec.
  • Great Britain National Championship, Elite Women, Sun 12th Jan: 1st Xan Crees, 54min 51sec; 2nd Cat Ferguson, +05sec; 3rd Imogen Wolff, +39sec.
  • Great Britain National Championship, Elite Men, Sun 12th Jan: 1st Cameron Mason, 1hr 03min 11sec; 2nd Ben Chilton, +3min 14sec; 3rd Dan Barnes, +3min 36sec.

Remco Evenepoel suffers nerve damage

The first half to the new season will look a little different for Remco Evenepoel, who has revealed he will be selective with which races he competes in to ensure he’s in full fitness for the Tour de France. This after the 24-year-old suffered fractures to his rib, right shoulder blade and hand, as well as lung contusions after colliding with the door of a postal vehicle in December last year.

Speaking to Sporza, the Belgian said recovery would be ‘longer than we thought’ because of nerve damage to his shoulder, so he definitely won’t be riding the Giro d’Italia and may not be ready for the Ardennes Classics. The 2025 Tour de France begins in Lille on Saturday 5th July and remains Evenepoel’s main goal for the year.

UCI bans sprint celebrations

Those iconic shots of riders celebrating as their teammate wins look set to be a thing of the past. As a new safety measure, any rider celebrating a teammate’s win in a bunch sprint risks a 500CHF (approx £450) fine, relegation to last place in the group and/or a yellow card.

A new revision relating to race incident rules from the UCI, section 5.2, prohibits a ‘rider decelerating during a sprint and endangering other riders (knowingly staying within the line of other riders, celebrating in the bunch, talking on the radio or taking hands off handlebars while in the bunch)’.

The fun police are at it again.

Bahrain Victorious launch new U23 development team

We are thrilled to announce the launch of the Bahrain Victorious Official Under-23 (U23) Development Team! #Nextgenracing #RideAsOne

https://t.co/FPBDnJXDhk pic.twitter.com/E0pFVLdlDE

— Team Bahrain Victorious (@BHRVictorious) January 13, 2025

Bahrain Victorious have announced that the Cycling Team Friuli U23 squad, which they have been partnered with since 2022, will now come under the Bahrain Victorious umbrella and be known as the Bahrain Victorious Development Team.

The concept remains the same as before. As a development pathway for youngsters aiming to head to the WorldTour, the team has previously seen the likes of Jonathan Milan pass through its ranks. Proximity with the WorldTour team means they can ride in ‘select non-WorldTour classified races’ too.

Cycling Team Friuli will ‘continue its grassroots efforts in the Friuli region, focussing on the other youth categories, as well as the Masters and amateur categories’.

New kits for EF teams and British Cycling

It was worth the wait. EF Education-EasyPost/EF-Oatly-Cannondale revealed their striking new kit for the 2025 season adorned with argyle diamonds and gems.

British Cycling also has new threads courtesy of Alé, marking the start of a four-year deal with the Italian brand, which takes over from Kalas.

FDJ-Suez get Nike on board

Another big new pairing sees Nike return to the cycling world. For 2025 the sportswear giant becomes FDJ-Suez’s ‘official lifestyle apparel supplier’. Both riders and staff will wear the clothing off the bike.

Demi Vollering has enjoyed a personal partnership with the sportswear brand since April 2024, so, like with the Specialized bike deal, she’s brought the brand with her to her new team.

Australian National Championships results

Australian summer is in full swing with National Championships taking place prior to the start of the Tour Down Under.

20-year-old Lucina Stewart (Liv-AlUla-Jayco Continental Team) prevailed in a four-up sprint to the line to win the Elite Women’s Road Race, while Luke ‘Turbo’ Durbridge led home a 1-2 with Jayco-AlUla teammate Luke Plapp for victory in the men’s event.

Alex Hewes (Gold Coast CC) and Anna Dubier (Lidcombe Auburn CC) won the junior titles while Julian Baudry attacked for victory in the men’s U23 race.

Full results:

  • Men’s Junior Individual Time-Trial, 19.2km, Weds 8th Jan: 1st Max Goold, Blackburn CC U19, 25min 11sec; 2nd Lucas Stevenson, Northern Sydney CC, +05sec; 3rd Fletcher Medway, Hamilton Wheelers CC Jr, +24sec. 
  • Women’s Junior Individual Time-Trial, 19.2km, Weds 8th Jan: 1st Amelie Sanders, Gold Coast CC, 29min 36sec; 2nd Georgia Gardner, Canberra CC ACT, +10sec; 3rd Leani van der Berg, Norwood CC, +20sec. 
  • Men’s U23 Individual Time-Trial, 28.8km, Weds 8th Jan: 1st Zac Marriage, Kilkenny CC, 35min 52sec; 2nd Fergus Browning, CCACHE x Bodywrap, +41sec; 3rd John Carter, CCACHE x Bodywrap, +1min 29sec.
  • Men’s Elite Individual Time-Trial, 38.4km, Thurs 9th Jan: 1st Luke Plapp, Jayco-AlUla, 46min 33sec; 2nd Jay Vine, UAE Team Emirates XRG, +08sec; 3rd Kelland O’Brien, Jayco AlUla, +54sec. 
  • Women’s Elite Individual Time-Trial, 28.8km, Thurs 9th Jan: 1st Brodie Chapman, UAE Team ADQ, 39min 53sec; 2nd Amber Pate, Liv AlUla Jayco, +32sec; 3rd Anya Louw, AG Insurance-Soudal Team, +1min. 
  • Men’s Criterium, Fri 10th Jan: 1st Sam Welsford, Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe, 1hr 04min 12sec; 2nd Cameron Scott, CCACHE x Bodywrap, +0sec; 3rd Blake Quick, Roojai Insurance, +0sec.
  • Women’s Criterium, Fri 10th Jan: 1st Amber Pate, Liv AlUla Jayco, 2nd Keira Will (U23 winner), Lidcombe Auburn CC, +19sec; 3rd Maeve Plouffe, Hess Cycling Team, +3min 55sec.
  • Men’s Junior Road Race, 109km, Sat 11th Jan: 1st Alex Hewes. Gold Coast CC, 2hr 33min 56sec; 2nd Jonas Shelverton, Hobart Wheelers, +0sec; 3rd Fletcher Medway, Hamilton Wheelers CC Jr, +0sec.
  • Women’s Junior Road Race, 81km, Sat 11th Jan: 1st Anna Dubier, Lidcombe Auburn CC, 2hr 23min; 2nd Amelie Sanders, Gold Coast CC, +0sec; 3rd Leani van der Berg, Norwood CC, +0sec.
  • Men’s U23 Road Race, 136km, Sat 11th Jan: 1st Julian Baudry, Atom-6-Decca, 3hr 05min 53sec; 2nd Fergus Browning, CCACHE x Bodywrap, 51sec; 3rd Jack Clark, New Energy Racing, 51sec.
  • Men’s Elite Road Race, 177km, Sun 12th Jan: 1st Luke Durbridge, Jayco-AlUla, 3hr 52min 19sec; 2nd Luke Plapp, Jayco-AlUla, +05; 3rd Liam Walsh, CCACHE x Bodywrap, +58sec.
  • Women’s Elite Road Race, 109km, Sun 12th Jan: 1st Lucinda Stewart, Liv AlUla Jayco Continental Team, 2hr 49min 59sec; 2nd Ella Simpson, St Michel-Preference Home-Auber 93, +0sec; 3rd Cassia Boglio, PAS Racing, +0sec.

See you next week.
